sub_topic: Find the Levi-Civita connection of a given metric.
message_1:
Given the metric tensor: 

$${g}_{ij}=
\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 2 & 0 \\
2 & 5 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 4
\end{bmatrix}
$$ 

Find the Levi-Civita connection of the metric tensor.
message_2:
To find the Levi-Civita connection (also known as the Christoffel symbols) of the given metric tensor, we use the following formula:

$$
\Gamma^k_{ij} = \frac{1}{2} g^{kl} \left(\frac{\partial g_{il}}{\partial x^j} + \frac{\partial g_{jl}}{\partial x^i} - \frac{\partial g_{ij}}{\partial x^l}\right)
$$

First, we need to find the inverse of the metric tensor $g^{ij}$:

$${g}^{ij}=
\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 2 & 0 \\
2 & 5 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 4
\end{bmatrix}^{-1}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
5 & -2 & 0 \\
-2 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & \frac{1}{4}
\end{bmatrix}
$$

Now, we can compute the partial derivatives of the metric tensor components with respect to the coordinates $x^i$, $x^j$, and $x^l$. Since the metric tensor components are constants, all the partial derivatives will be zero:

$$
\frac{\partial g_{il}}{\partial x^j} = \frac{\partial g_{jl}}{\partial x^i} = \frac{\partial g_{ij}}{\partial x^l} = 0
$$

Finally, we can compute the Christoffel symbols using the formula:

$$
\Gamma^k_{ij} = \frac{1}{2} g^{kl} \left(\frac{\partial g_{il}}{\partial x^j} + \frac{\partial g_{jl}}{\partial x^i} - \frac{\partial g_{ij}}{\partial x^l}\right) = 0
$$

Since all the partial derivatives are zero, the Levi-Civita connection (Christoffel symbols) for the given metric tensor are all zero:

$$
\Gamma^k_{ij} = 0
$$
